heading: at&t boosted by wireless, data
subheading: revenues from consumer long-distance fell, but the company managed to match the wall street forecast by picking up the pace in other areas.
author: wired news report
text: at&t on monday reported higher 1998 fourth-quarter profits of nearly us$2 billion, matching wall street expectations, as strength in its business and wireless subscribers offset a decline in its core consumer long-distance operations. at&t's (t) net income increased 57 percent from a year earlier, to $1.99 billion or $1.12 a share, from $1.26 billion, or 70 cents, in the same 1997 quarter. excluding one-time charges, at&t's income from continuing operations rose to $1 a share from 69 cents a year ago, matching the first call consensus forecast.consumer service revenues -- that's mostly long-distance phone sales -- fell 3.6 percent to $5.54 billion amid intense competition, a shift in customers to special rate plans, and an increase in the use of wireless phone service instead of more expensive calling-card or other long-distance services.those wireless services posted strong gains, with revenue up 25 percent from the fourth quarter of 1997 to $302 million. the company credited its digital one rate plan, which charges customers a flat rate regardless of where their call is made from or to, with boosting revenue in the sector. digital one rate has gained 850,000 subscribers since the service was launched in may.overall, business service revenues increased 4.7 percent, to $5.74 billion from $5.49 billion due to continued strong demand for data services, particularly in frame-relay and high-speed private line services.the 1998 fourth-quarter results included a $313 million pre-tax gain for the settlement of pension obligations for former employees who accepted an early-retirement offer. the year-ago results included a $42 million pre-tax gain for changes in accounting for software development costs.reuters contributed to this report.
